pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw:
Do you mean this code in particular, or all of the places where I remove variables we assign to but then subsequently don't use?

IMO creating variables that aren't used later is confusing, since creating a local variable indicates to the reader that you will do something with it. Python is tough in that functions can have both side effects and return values :(

That said, the rules we'all be enforcing if this PR goes in are up for debate. I can add this rule to the ignore list if the consensus is that it's not a good fit for our development community.
content.html:
Do you mean this code in particular, or all of the places where I remove variables we assign to but then subsequently don't use?

IMO creating variables that aren't used later is confusing, since creating a local variable indicates to the reader that you will do something with it. Python is tough in that functions can have both side effects and return values :(

That said, the rules we'all be enforcing if this PR goes in are up for debate. I can add this rule to the ignore list if the consensus is that it's not a good fit for our development community.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw: I mean these specific instances where instead of creating a variable that we never use, we're calling a function and not capturing its or accessing some variable without assigning it to anything.  Maybe one is not better than the other, but I think in this specific example, they are equally bad.  I guess I'm just advocating for a little manual combing in specific instances like this, although I know that is a pain.
content.html: I mean these specific instances where instead of creating a variable that we never use, we're calling a function and not capturing its or accessing some variable without assigning it to anything. Maybe one is not better than the other, but I think in this specific example, they are equally bad. I guess I'm just advocating for a little manual combing in specific instances like this, although I know that is a pain.

content.raw: I like the idea of not having duplicate style guides, but why not just have the coding styleguide *in* the docs instead of as a text file in the docs directory?  I'm not sure a lot of people are looking through the docs directory in the repository looking for non rst files.
content.html: I like the idea of not having duplicate style guides, but why not just have the coding styleguide in the docs instead of as a text file in the docs directory? I'm not sure a lot of people are looking through the docs directory in the repository looking for non rst files.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw:
What do you think about moving it to the root of the repository? @MatthewTurk can you weigh in here?

I want the coding style guide to be near the code, not buried in the docs. Not everyone who checks out the code will see the style guide in the docs.
content.html:
What do you think about moving it to the root of the repository? Matt Turk can you weigh in here?

I want the coding style guide to be near the code, not buried in the docs. Not everyone who checks out the code will see the style guide in the docs.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw: The styleguide doesn't seem like it's for people trying to *read* the source, it seems like it's for people trying to hack on and build the source.  For that, I think they should consult the docs.  If we have too much of a diaspora of information in too many places, it provides a mixed message.  I think the #1 place where people should go to figure out how to do X (including develop new code) is the compiled documentation.
content.html: The styleguide doesn't seem like it's for people trying to read the source, it seems like it's for people trying to hack on and build the source. For that, I think they should consult the docs. If we have too much of a diaspora of information in too many places, it provides a mixed message. I think the #1 place where people should go to figure out how to do X (including develop new code) is the compiled documentation.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw: Yup, I agree that the developer guide is important. That's why it's in the built docs (in case you missed it, in this PR I include the style guide in the built docs). It's just not in the source of the docs, which I don't think there is a high likelihood of a new developer looking at. I think having it in a separate document that sits with the code makes it easier to discover for new developers.
content.html: Yup, I agree that the developer guide is important. That's why it's in the built docs (in case you missed it, in this PR I include the style guide in the built docs). It's just not in the source of the docs, which I don't think there is a high likelihood of a new developer looking at. I think having it in a separate document that sits with the code makes it easier to discover for new developers.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw: I may be in the minority here, and I'm willing to be overruled, but I think if we want any sort of "discoverable" for developers to find in the source of this type, it should just be a note saying "if you want to hack on the code, check out the developer docs" and shuffle them over there.
content.html: I may be in the minority here, and I'm willing to be overruled, but I think if we want any sort of "discoverable" for developers to find in the source of this type, it should just be a note saying "if you want to hack on the code, check out the developer docs" and shuffle them over there.

content.raw: @chummels take a look at what @ngoldbaum does.  He's using the `..include` directive *in the source file of the docs* so that it includes the file.  This reduces duplication, and still allows it to be in text form in the main doc directory.  I think this is like, the most wins possible?
content.html: chummels take a look at what Nathan Goldbaum does. He's using the ..include directive in the source file of the docs so that it includes the file. This reduces duplication, and still allows it to be in text form in the main doc directory. I think this is like, the most wins possible?

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw:
Yes, I saw this.  I'm just a fan of having all of the documentation for the code actually existing in the documentation instead of multiple locations, even if they're all referencing the same document.  If we start to have docs in lots of different places (e.g. BB wiki, docs page, readthedocs, source directory txt files, website, etc. etc.) it provides multiple places where users are supposed to look for things.  By placing all of the relevant information in a single place: ie the docs page, it provides a one-stop shop where people are expected to go for help when they run into problems.

As I said, I'm not going to veto this, but I think just making it so the expectation is that people go to one place for help is the best policy.
content.html:
Yes, I saw this. I'm just a fan of having all of the documentation for the code actually existing in the documentation instead of multiple locations, even if they're all referencing the same document. If we start to have docs in lots of different places (e.g. BB wiki, docs page, readthedocs, source directory txt files, website, etc. etc.) it provides multiple places where users are supposed to look for things. By placing all of the relevant information in a single place: ie the docs page, it provides a one-stop shop where people are expected to go for help when they run into problems.

As I said, I'm not going to veto this, but I think just making it so the expectation is that people go to one place for help is the best policy.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw: I think this is something that we should figure out, though, as a general policy.  It's the same information, and there's no way it can diverge since it's included in both directly, like a header file is `#include`'d.  I think having it live in the top-level of the source repository is great, and I also think that it should be in the documentation, and this seems like an elegant approach.  Your concerns about fragmentation are good, but we're not actually directing people to different places -- this allows for *both* discoverability (which I think is increased by having something code-centric next to the codebase) as well as reduction of fragmentation.
content.html: I think this is something that we should figure out, though, as a general policy. It's the same information, and there's no way it can diverge since it's included in both directly, like a header file is #include'd. I think having it live in the top-level of the source repository is great, and I also think that it should be in the documentation, and this seems like an elegant approach. Your concerns about fragmentation are good, but we're not actually directing people to different places -- this allows for both discoverability (which I think is increased by having something code-centric next to the codebase) as well as reduction of fragmentation.

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

content.raw:
Yup, one import per line. You can have more than one "from blah import for, bar, baz" per line though.

This is a pep8 rule, and AFAICS the major reason for doing it is it makes it easier for new coders to read the file if they're used to pep8.

This StackOverflow answer is a good summary about why it's a good practice for maintainability: http://stackoverflow.com/a/25027300/1382869
content.html:
Yup, one import per line. You can have more than one "from blah import for, bar, baz" per line though.

This is a pep8 rule, and AFAICS the major reason for doing it is it makes it easier for new coders to read the file if they're used to pep8.

This StackOverflow answer is a good summary about why it's a good practice for maintainability: http://stackoverflow.com/a/25027300/1382869

pullrequest.title: Linting yt.data_objects, yt.utilities, and top-level yt.* submodules. Adding a flake8 test

description:
This includes the following linting commits:

* Linting the ytdata frontend

* Fixing flake issues in analysis modules that have come in the last few weeks

* Linting yt.utilities

* Linting top-level submodules in the yt namespace

    This also brings in several other files outside of the top-level namespace due
    to transitive import issues. We now make an effort to import symbols from the
    files where the symbol is defined rather than transitively importing symbols,
    particularly via "import *"

I've also removed some unused code:

* Removing boolean data objects

    These are currently untested, not being used, and would take a lot of work
    to get working again. Rather than leaving the dead code in the codebase I am
    removing it in the interest of code clarity. If someone wants to bring it back
    they can use the VCS history to restore the code.

* Removing BinnedProfile code

    This code is untested, deprecated, and known to no longer function correctly
    under yt-3. Rather than confusing users by still allowing them to import it,
    I'm removing it completely here. People should use create_profile and ProfileND
    subclasses instead.

* Removing tests in the top-level tests folder and old answer testing support

    These tests are not run by the current testing infrastructure. In the interest
    of clarity to new users (who might think these tests are useful since they are
    at the root of the repository) I'm removing them. I've left in the test enzo
    dataset to avoid adding 2.4 MB to the repository.

I've also done some minor adjustments to the flake8 rules and added a unit test for flake8 issues.

* Small adjustments to flake8 fules, adding clarifying comments to explain why
    we ignore certain files

* Adding a test for flake8 issues to the unit tests

In the future we can make these rules more or less strict by deleting or adding rules to the the list of ignored rules in setup.cfg.

Finally, I've also:

* Updated the style guide. Deleting the copy of the style guide in the docs and including the guide directly.
